chapter.title: Introduction
chapter.para: Support for a limited set of CAEN digitizers running either DPP-PHA or DPP-PSD firmware by CAEN and has been contributed back to NSCLDAQ as of version 12.0. This document describes:

listitem.para: How to build NSCLDAQ with this optional support included and the software pre-requisistes needed to perform this build.
An overview of the support.
How to create a readout program for DPP-PHA digitizers.
How to create a readout program for DPP-PSD digitizers
How to create a readout program that mixes DPP-PHA and DPP-PSD digitizers.
How to configure the ReadoutGUI and event builder to use these devices.
Guidance on writing SpecTcl event processors for this sort of data.

chapter.title: Overview
chapter.para: Support for the CAEN digitizers is provided through classes that allow the SBSreadout skeleton to read data from synchronized sets of these digitizers. Separate class sets have been made availabl for the DPP-PHA and DPP-PSD digitizers.

Each of these digitizers has a large number of parameters that must be set up properly to optimize pulse processing performed on-board. CAEN supplies a setup/acquisition tool called COMPASS which can be used to configure these parameters and see the effect of parameter set choices on spectra produced by the digitizers.

COMPASS is available for free download from . COMPASS can work with single digitizers or with groups of digitizers and can be used to create parameter sets for synchronized sets of digitizers. These parameter sets are written to XML configuration files.

The NSCLDAQ support classes set up the digitizers they manage by processing the XML configuration files that were written by COMPASS. These configuration files are processed at the start of each run, allowing the digitizer settings to be modified beteween runs.

Data from digitizers consists of a sequence of time ordered events from each independent digitizer. Each digitizer event represents data from a single channel. Channel events are timestamped. The sorted event streams from each digitizer must be merged into a single time ordered stream of channel events and then coincident events built into meaningful events.

The NSCL Event builder was created for exactly that purpose. THerefore, when the SBS readout program has been tailored to read CAEN digitizer events, each digitizer card is assigned a unique source id. This allows the NSCL Event builder to merge and glom events across all digitizers.
We will say more about the special requirements for using the SBS readout program with the NSCLDAQ Event builder in a later chapter.

chapter.title: Creating event segments for DPP-PHA digitizers
chapter.para: This chapter describes how to create a version of the SBS readout program that can setup and read data from the DPP-PHA digitizers. The steps you need to follow are roughly:

Edit the skeleton code to include the digitizers you want to read.
Compile and test the code you've written.
Configure the ReadoutGUi to run the event builder to build events from the channel events that are produced by the Readout. This will be described in a later chapter.

chapter.para: In addition to describing this process we'll also provide a definition of the structure of the bodies of ring items produced by the resulting readout.

caution.title: You cannot mix CAEN DPP digitizers with non CAEN digitizers
caution.para: The readout requirements of the CAEN DPP digitizers are unique enough that you cannot mix reading out the CAEN digitizers with non-CAEN digitizers in a single Readout program. What you can do, however is read CAEN Digitizers via the CONET fiber optic link and have a second readout program read the non CAEN DPP digitizers via a VME controller from the same VME crate using, an SBS VME bus bridge or VMUSBReadout with a VM-USB controller.

section.title: Structure of data read by the DPP-PHA skeleton
section.para: This section describes the format of the data readout by the DPP-PHA readout program. Note that usually, individual channel hits are assembled into events using the NSCL event builder. The wrapping of data by the NSCL Event builder is beyond the scope of this document. See the NSCLDAQ event builder documentation for that information.

Before going into the event structure in detail, a note about timestamps. The V725 and V730 boards have a different timestamp clock rate. The readout framework adjusts the timestamps from both boards so that the event is tagged with a timestamp in nanoseconds. This allows the event builder to properly build data from these boards (and e.g. XIA DDAS boards as well) correctly).
Here's a text picture of the structure of each hit's body: Note that the body header contains the source id, which in turn tells you which module this packet comes from.

callout.para: This is not the raw time tag from the digitizer. The digitizer has a 32 bit timestamp with an optional 16 bit extension that could be put in the one of the extras (see below). This timestamp can only cover a relatively short period of time (a few seconds). Therefore, the readout program tracks wrap arounds (this is fine as long as there are not two wraps between hits), and calibrates the resulting tag to nanoseconds. This value is the 64 bit nanosecond timestamp that also accounts for raw stamp rollovers.
A quick note that there are no pad words. Event data is tight packed.

In addition to the results of the DPP algorithm, extra words can be included in the data depending on how the digitizer is configured. These two words are called Extras 1 and Extras 2. Their contents depend on how you've configured the digitizer.

Waveform data can be included. Up to two traces of data can be put into the event depending on the configuration of the digitzer. Waveform data may also be completely suppressed, if that's how the digitizer is configured. The form of waveform data is shown below:

section.para: The digitizer can record two waveforms per channel. The contents of these waveforms depends on the digitizer configuration. The waveform packet begins with a uint32_t that contains the number of samples in each trace (if there are two traces both have the same number of samples). If no traces are recorded, this value is 0.

Following the number of samples is a dual trace flag. This is present even if no waveforms are being recorded. This flag is nonzero if waveforms are being recorded and there will be two of them. Otherwise, this flag is zero.

callout.para: This packet of contains one uint16_t trace value per sample. Naturally, if the number of samples is zero, there will be no data words here.

This packet is only present if the dual trace flag is nonzero. It contains the second trace. Note, once more this contains a 16 bit integer per trace value. This is omitted if the number of samples is zero or the dual trace flag is zero but the number of samples is nonzero.

section.title: Cheat files
section.para: Sometimes there are tweaks you will want to make to the digitizer configuration that are not supported by Compass or not well supported by the implementation at this time. Once the digitizer is configured but before it is started, you can optionally process a cheat file

The cheat file specifies changes to the configuration of the digitizer. The cheat file is optionally specified when the digitizer is constructed. If omitted, no cheats will be applied. Each cheat file line consists of three space separated fields.

listitem.para: The first field is a single character that specifies an operation.
The second field is an address, usually a register address.
The final field is a value.

section.para: Cheat files can also have empty lines and lines that begin with a #. These lines are ignored.
Here are the operations and what they do:

listitem.para: The address is the address of a register. The value is set into the register.
The address is the address of a register. The value is bitwise ored into the register's current value.
The address is the address of a register. The value is bitwise anded with the register.
The address is a channel number. The value is one of the legal values of its pile up rejection counters in the digitizer. The value can be 128, 1024, or 8192.
The address is ignored. The value is a proposed value for the module's aggregate transfer threshold. This is the second parameter to the function CAEN_DGTZ_SetDPPEventAggregation

chapter.title: Creating event segments for DPP-PSD digitizers
chapter.para: The DPP-PSd firmware allows CAEN digitizers to perform pulse shape discrimination. This involves integrating the background subtracted pulse within two integration windows, a short and a long window.

This chapter will describe how to create event segments for the DPP-PSD firmware in CAEN x730 and x725 modules. While it is possible to mix DPP-PSD and DPP-PHA modules it is not possible to mix CAEN DPP modules with other types of modules in the same Readout program. Mixing DPP-PSD and DPP-PHA modules will be described in the next chapter.
This chapter is divided into the following sections:

listitem.para: First we describe how to get the skeleton for DPP-PSD readout.
Next we describe how to modify the skeleton to readout the set of digitizers you are using.
We describe how to build the resulting Readout program.
Finally we describe the structure of events readout from the DPP-PSD digitizers.

section.title: Event format from the DPP-PSD readout.
section.para: This section describes the format for each hit (channel event) from the PSD digitizers. Normally, hits are sent to an event builder where they are wrapped in event builder headers and bundled into events that consist of hits that have occured within some time period of a first hit.

This section will describe the raw body of hits produced by the Readout program prior to event building. Each event is a ring item of type PHYSICS_EVENT. These events have the standard body header that carries the timestamp and source id among other things. The actual body of the event follows the body header and has the following structure:

callout.para: The timestamp in the raw hit from the digitizer is 32 bits wide and is in digitizer size specific units. This has two problems. First, 32 bits of timestamp only allow for a few seconds of run time before the timestamp rolls over. Second, device specific units of the raw timestamp would make event building with a heterogeneous set of digitizers impossible. The event builder expects all data sources to be running at the same timestamp frequency.

The timestamp in the event body is computed using wrap detection and a carry counter to produce a true 64 bit timestamp in the device units. This timestamp is accurate as long as the channel it comes from does not roll over more than once between hits.

The resulting timestamp is then multiplied by the number of nanoseconds per digitizer timestamp tick and the resulting timestamp in nanoseconds is put into the event's body header. The event builder only cares about the body header. This allows all digitizers to present timestamps with a common time base (nanosecond units) to the event builder.

Note that the software supporting XIA Pixie16 modules also presents body header timestamps in nanosecond units making it possible to directly build XIA and CAEN digital data acquisition system event fragments together.

section.para: The remainder of the event structure should be self explanatory from the description of the digitizer, with the exception of the waveform data. Note that the digitizer this hit came from can be deduced from the source id located in the hit's body header.

Note in this version, the extras are hard coded to be the an additional top 16 bits of timestamp (raw which should be ignored) in the top 16 bits, Flag information of some sort in bits 10-15 and the bottom 10 bits (bits 0-9) the fine timestamp from the CFD. We chose this so that we can unambiguously unpack a high precision time in SpecTcl e.g. for the computation of time differences as might be needed for time of flight parameters. A later version will support the full set of selections available in COMPASS.
The digitizers can be told to acquire waveforms. The structure of waveform data is as follows:

callout.para: Provides the number of bytes of waveform data. The size is inclusive of this longword. Note that if there is not waveform data, this will be sizeof(uint32_t). That indicates there is no data following the size word.

This and subsequent words are only present if there is trace data (the prior longword is not sizeof(uint32_t)). In that case, this is the number of samples in each trace. Note that in dual trace mode, both traces have the same number of samples, making it unecessary to have two trace lengths.
This byte is non-zero if there are two traces or zero if only one.

This word along with the dual trace flag describes the meaning of the data in the trace(s). This is essentially the value of the board configuration register bits 12,13. The meaning of these bits depends on whether dual trace is enabled.
If dual trace is not enabled, a value of zero means the trace is the input waveform. A value of 1 means the trace is the CFD waveform.

If dual trace is enabled; A value of zero means the first trace is the input waveform while the second trace is the runnning baseline determination. A value of 1 means that the first trace is the CFD and the second trace, again the running baseline determination. A value of 2 means that the first trace is the input waveform and the second trace the CFD.
If only it were that simple. The CFD trace is only available if CFD discrimination is enabled. If it is disabled, then the "CFD" trace is actually the smoothed input trace.
Note that the second trace is not present unless the dual trace flag is nonzero.

chapter.title: Creating Readouts that mix DPP-PSD and DPP-PHA segments
chapter.para: There are two ways to mix DPP-PSD and DPP-PHA event segments.

listitem.para: Use one readout program for the DPP-PHA digitizers and a second for the DPP-PSD digitizers.
Use a single readout and combine the data from both digitizers.

chapter.para: Note that whichever you choose, you must determine which of the digitizers is the master timing source on the daisy chain and configure both types of digitizers accordingly. Using the COMPASS synchronization wizard can help you with this.

If you use two readouts, you can stil have a common XML configuration file as both programs can locate their digitizers from within the XML configuration and will ignore digitizers they've not been told about.
The remainder of this chapter will describe how to merge data from both digitizers into a single readout program. Briefly here are the steps to follow:

listitem.para: Obtain the DPP-PSD skeleton.
Add appropriate #include definitions to pull in the class headers you need from the DPP-PHA framework.
Edit the skeleton to make DPP-PSD event segments and a CDPpPsdCompoundEventSegment as you normally would for configuring the the skeleton
Add to that configuration the CompassEventSegment objects and CompassMultiModuleEventSegment as you normally would for the DPP-PHA skeleton.

Create a COneOnlyEventSegment object and insert into it both the CDPpPsdCompoundEventSegment and the CCompassMultiModuleEventSegement you created in the previous steps. Register that object as Readout's event segment.
Create and fill both CPsdTrigger and CompassTrigger objects as you would for the DPP-PSD and DPP-PHA skeletons.
Create a CCompoundTrigger object and insert both the DPP-PHA and DPP-PSD trigger objects into it. Then register this compound trigger object as the event trigger.
Note the DPP-PSD skeleton already links both the DPP-PSD and PP-PHA support libraries so no modification should be required.

section.title: Editing the SetupReadout method
section.para: Now let's look at the combined SetupReadout implementation. If you're not yet familiar with building Readout programs that can read DPP-PSD and DPP-PHA modules by themselves, become familiar now. This discussion assumes that familiarity.

Similarly, this section of code creates an event segment with a single DPP-PHA board. You can expand that cde to have as many DPP-PHA boards as you need.

The COneOnlyEventSegment class is a container for event segments. The SBS readout framework supplies a compound event segment already, but that segment glues all contained event segments that have data to supply into a single event. This is not suitable for use here as we want each hit to live in its own ring item.

The COneOnlyEventSegment, like the compound event segments for DPP-PHA or DPP-PSD segments stops asking event segments for data once one of them supplies data. Like the DPP-PHA and DPP-PSD segments, it does a round robbin polling to ensure that DPP-PSD does not starve out DPP-PHA or vica versa.
Here we add the DPP-PSD compound event segment we generated to the overall compound segment for the event.
Similarly we add the DPP-PHA segment.
Finally the COneOnlyEventSegment compound event segement is set as the experiments event segment.

Similarly a PHA trigger is created and the PHA module added to it.

A compound trigger is a container trigger. It's trigger check method will return the OR of all of its component triggers. Creating this trigger object allows us to combine the trigger for both the PSD and PHA modules.
Adds the PSD trigger to the compound trigger object.

Establishing the compound trigger as the event trigger allows the Readout to initiate a readout if either a PHA module or a PSD module have data.

chapter.title: Configuring the Event builder and ReadoutGUI to create events.
chapter.para: CAEN Digitizer Readout programs treat each module in the sysem as a unique data source. Each module produces a time ordered sequence of hits. But the data read across modules does not guarantee a totally time ordered set of fragments across all modules in the system.
Treating each module as a separate data source requires a few special bits of handling when setting up the event builder.

listitem.para: Since Readout only issues one Begin run and End run ring item, but has several data sources, the Readout program must be configured to not mark these records with a barrier type. Otherewise at the start and end of each run, the event builder will stall on a barrier wait until there's a barrier timeout.

The source id given to the Readout program should match one of the module sourceids. That ensures that the non physics hit ring items (Begin run, end run, pause run, esuem run, scaler, trigger count), are emitted with a source id that is one of the module sourceids. This is a best practice, you can use an additional source id just for those records. See below, however.
The ring fragment source(s) for the event builder must be configured to accept data from all source ids their Readout's emit.

chapter.para: Let's look at an example where the Readout program has three modules, configured for source id 1, 2 and 3. The Readout program must haved the following command line options specified in its data source specification in the ReadoutShell:

listitem.para: As usual this must be supplied and should specify a ring buffer into which the raw hit data will be put.
As a best practice, this should specify one of the source ids (e.g. 1) configured for one of the module event segment objects.

Turns off barrier synchronization. This must be specified for ALL readout programs in the event builder, not just the CAEN ones. If any Readout program doesn not have this flag, the event builder will stall until a barrier timeout at all run state transitions.

chapter.para: The ReadoutGUI's ReadoutCallouts.tcl file specifies both the use of the event builder and ring fragment sources that will take data from the raw ring item rings, package them up and send them off to the event builder.

chapter.title: caendump
chapter.para: When troubleshooting a configuration it can sometimes be useful to look at the contents of digitizer registers. caendump is a program that provide that dump.
Here's the usage text you get if you just issue the command $DAQBIN/caendump

informalexample.programlisting: Can't find registers.txt - register definition file Usage caendump linktype linknum node [base] linktype: 0 USB, 1 Optical base is needed if the link is to a VME bus bridge and is the module's base address Note the file registers.txt will be read in in the cwd to decide which registers to dump.

chapter.para: Note the first line. It says that there must be a file named registers.txt must exits in the current working directory. This file describes the registers you want to dump. The file is a text file that is made up of lines that contain three fields. In order:

varlistentry.term: The textual name of the register

listitem.para: This should not have any whilespace. Legal examples: Acquisition or DPP_Control. DPP Control is not legal.
This text labels the data dumped for that register.

For VME interfaces, this is the offset from the module base address at which the register is located. You can get this value from the CAEN register level documentation for the module, which you need to interpret the output in any event.

Some registers have an instance per channel. These have base addresses in the CAEN documentation that look like anbc where, a,b,c are hex digits and n is the literal n. For these registers, specify a base address of a0bc and set this flag to be 1 to dump all 16 registers.
For single registers, whose addresses are given in the form abcd where a,b,c and d are hex digits, give the base address as documented and set the flag to 0.

chapter.para: The command line parameters for caendump supply the connection parameters to allow the program to access the desired digitizer.

listitem.para: Is the manner in which the digitizer is connected to the host computer. 0 should be used for VME USB controllers or for USB connected desktop digitizers. 1 should be used for optically connected digitizers e.g. VME CONET controllers or digitizers directly connected by fiber optics.

The integer link number connected to the digitizer or the VME interface controlling the digitizer crate. Refer to the discussion in
for constructing an event segment to determine the value of this term.
Used only in CONET connections. This is the node number of the target on the CONET daisy chain.
If the module is interfaced via a VME controller, this is its VME base address configured into the module's rotary switches.

appendix.title: Reference material
appendix.para: For the most part, this material can be ignored by end users. This section is provided for completeness to document the set of classes and structs that form the support code.
This appendix is divided into two sections. The first documents the DPP-PHA support clases and the second, the DPP-PSD support classes.

section.title: DPP-PHA support classes.
section.para: The DPP-PHA support classes went through couple of iterations. The first version was built to operate with the configuration files used by a discontinued CAEN Product called MC2A. CAEN released the more functional COMPASS data acquisition tool. The original customers then requested that the DPP-PHA support operate with the XML based configuration files written by that program.
The original support therefore mostly still exists as a layer of code in this second iteration.
Note tht the pugixml library, included in the CAEN DPP support is used to do XML parsing. For information about this library see

refnamediv.refpurpose: Capture per channel parameters and their parsing.

Supports copy construction.

refsect1.title: PUBLIC DATA and TYPES.
refsect1.para: The configuration object contains a lot of configurtion data for both the raw digitizer and the DPP algorithm.

formalpara.title: Polarity enumerated type
formalpara.para: Provide allowed values for the signal polarity. As you can imagine, the value of this type can be either positive indicating the signal has positive polarity or negative indicating the signal is a negative going pulse.

formalpara.title: Copuling enumerated type
formalpara.para: Provides an enumerated type that specifies the input coupling of the signal. This can be either ac or dc.

refsect1.para: The list below describes the member data that provides the full parameterization of the digitizer channel. Board level parameters are stored elsewhere.

listitem.para: If false the channel is completely disabled and will not respond to triggers. If true, the channel is enabled to respond to triggers.
The DC offset that will be applied to the signal. This is a value from 0 through 65535 covering the ADC range.

If decimation is enabled, this is a selector that selects the decimation factor. It is a value in the range [0..3]. A value of 0 disables input decimation. A value of 1 sets the decimation to accept only every other sample. A value of 2 selects a decimation factor of 4 and a value of 3 selects a decimation factor of 8.

Sets the digital gain value. This is a value in the range [0..3]. Where: 0 means a digital gain of 1, 1 means a digital gain of 2, 2 means a digitial gain of 4 and 3 means a digital gain of 8. Note that the digital gain requires a decimation of at least the gain value. Thuse If you set this value to 3, the decimation must be either 3 or 4.
The input signal polarity. Note that for negative going signals it's necessary to adjust the DC Offset so that the signal will live in the dynamic range of the ADC.
Input range selector for the digitizer. 0 selects 2Vpp range whle 1 selects 0.5Vpp range.
Describes the optimized signal decay time in us. This will be converted to register units by the software. Note that the register units are digitzer type dependent and are set in register 1x68.
The rise-time parameter of the trapezoidal filter. The value is represented in microseconds and the software will convert that to digitizer type dependent register values stored in register 1n5c.

Selects where in the flattop region of the trapezoidal filter the energy value is gotten. This is expressed in microseconds and converted to digitizer dependent units by the software before being stored in register 0x1n64.
The width of the flattop expressed in microseconds. The software will convert this to digitzer dependent units which are stored in register 1n60.

Selects the baseline averaging window. This is a value in the range [0..6]: 0 means there's no baseline subtraction. 1 means the baseline is based on a 16 sample running average up until the baseline computation is frozen. 2 means the baseline is a running average of 64 samples. 3 means the baseline is a running average of 64 samples, 4 means the baseline is a running average of 1024 samples, 5 means the baseline is a running average of 4096 samples an 6 means the baseline is a running average of 16384 samples.
This value is programmed into bits 20-22 of register 1n80.
Become the value of the enf field of the CAEN_DGTZ_PHA_Params_t struct, the energy renormalization factor, sent to CAEN_DGTZ_SetDPPParameters.

Code selectin gthe nuber of samples for the peak mean. This is a value in the range [0..3]: 0 - 1 sample, 1 4 samples, 2 16 samples, 3 64 samples. This becomes the nspk field of the CAEN_DGTZ_PHA_Params_t struct sent to CAEN_DGTZ_SetDPPParameters.
The baseline hold off in nanoseconds. This becomes the value of the blho field in the CAEN_DGTZ_PHA_Params_t struct sent to CAEN_DGTZ_SetDPPParameters.
The peak hold off in nanoseconds. This becomes the value of the pkho field in the CAEN_DGTZ_PHA_Params_t struct sent to CAEN_DGTZ_SetDPPParameters.
The trigger threshold in digitizer conversion units. This becomes the value of the thr field in the CAEN_DGTZ_PHA_Params_t struct sent to CAEN_DGTZ_SetDPPParameters.

The smootyhing factor for the trigger filter. This is the number of samples averaged to compute the value compared to the trigger threshold. This becomes the a fiedld of the CAEN_DGTZ_PHA_Params_t struct sent to CAEN_DGTZ_SetDPPParameters.
This value has one of [value (meaning)]: 0 (no smoothing), 1 (2 samples), 4 (8 samples), 8 (16 samples), 16 (32 samples), 32 (64 samples), 127 (128 samples).
The input rise time of the expected pulses in nanoseconds. This becomes the b field of the CAEN_DGTZ_PHA_Params_t struct sent to CAEN_DGTZ_SetDPPParameters.
The trigger hold off in nanoseconds. This becomes the trgho field of the CAEN_DGTZ_PHA_Params_t struct sent to CAEN_DGTZ_SetDPPParameters.
The zero crossing acceptance window for the Rise Time Discrimminator for pile up rejection in samples. Become the twwt field of the CAEN_DGTZ_PHA_Params_t struct sent to CAEN_DGTZ_SetDPPParameters.
Pretrigger in nanoseconds.
Becomes the enskip field of the CAEN_DGTZ_PHA_Params_t struct sent to CAEN_DGTZ_SetDPPParameters. As of the rev 18 version of the CAENDigitizer library, this is undocumented.
Becomes the eskimlld field of the CAEN_DGTZ_PHA_Params_t struct sent to CAEN_DGTZ_SetDPPParameters. As of the rev 18 version of the CAENDigitizer library, this is undocumented.
Becomes the eskimhld field of the CAEN_DGTZ_PHA_Params_t struct sent to CAEN_DGTZ_SetDPPParameters. As of the rev 18 version of the CAENDigitizer library, this is undocumented.
Becomes the dcomp field of the CAEN_DGTZ_PHA_Params_t struct sent to CAEN_DGTZ_SetDPPParameters. As of the rev 18 version of the CAENDigitizer library, this is undocumented.
Becomes the brlclip field of the CAEN_DGTZ_PHA_Params_t struct sent to CAEN_DGTZ_SetDPPParameters. As of the rev 18 version of the CAENDigitizer library, this is undocumented.
Becomes the trapbsl field of the CAEN_DGTZ_PHA_Params_t struct sent to CAEN_DGTZ_SetDPPParameters. As of the rev 18 version of the CAENDigitizer library, this is undocumented.

Determines, in conjunction with the desired fine gain, rise time and decay time values, the value of register 1n4c, the fine gain register. See the description of ths register in the CAEN Register description for xx730/xx725 digitizers with PHA firmware.

refsect1.title: DESCRIPTION
refsect1.para: This class manages a single module. It provides methods that allow it to setup a module, shutdown a module and get data. Interfaces for trigger and synchronization are also present.

listitem.para: Constructs a module control object. config provides the configuration of the digitizer as a whole as well as for each channel. linkType, linknum, node and base describe how the dgitizer is connected to the host computer.

startMode describes how the digitizer is started. The master is started by software, all others in a synchronized set are started by hardware and signals triggered by the master startup. trgout is true if the trigger output will be used. delay is a start delay. This is used to get precise clock synchronization by compensating for the increasing delays in start propagation as you get more removed down the start daisy chain from the master module.
If a cheat file is required to adjust register contents, the pCheatFile can be provided with the path to that file. If omitted, no cheat file will be processed.
Called to initialize the digitizer. The digitizer is initialized but not started.
Disables the digitizer. This is normally called as a data taking run is ended.
Returns the number of nanoseconds per digitizer clock period. This is needed to compute digitizer units for several parameters provided by compass in nanosecond units.
Interface to support data based triggering this returns true when the digitizer has at least one hit in its data buffer memories.

Reads the next event from the digiitzer. Internal buffering is used. This event is either satisified from the buffer or the digitizer is read to re-fill the internal buffer. The tuple returned includes the channel number of the hit. The hit event data and any waveforms associated with the hit.
Returns true if this board is a master board. This is determined by the start mode. Master boards haved software start modes.
Starts the master board. Prior to this startSlave must have been called on all the slave boards.

Arms a slave board to be started when the start signal it's programmed to use is detected. The start sequence needed to get a synchronized start is to start all the slave boards and then start the master board.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Encapsulate and parse all module configuration parameters.

refsect1.title: DESCRIPTION
refsect1.para: This class contains the configuration of one DPP-PHA module. Note that the processing/parsing parts of this class are obsolete and no longer used. See CompassProject instead.
CompassProject decodes the COMPASS configuration file and fills in this struct as well as the m_channelParameters vector that contains the channel configuration parameters for each enabled channel.

refsect1.title: METHODS

listitem.para: In the original support version that was based on MC2Analyzer, only part of the configuration was expressed by the textual configuration files written for that program. The additional configuration was read in via simple XML configuration files. This constructor was coded for that purpose. As such it is deprecated.

dom is the parsed XML file for the additional digitizer module level configuration parameters not captured by MC2Analyzer. channelDoms are the parsed XML files for each enabled channel of the digitizer containing per channel configuration parameters not captured by MC2Analyzer's configuration file.
Again, I want to stress that this constructor is no longer used and is deprecated as we use a different method to fill in this configuration from COMPASS configuration files.
The default constructor is now used because the COMPASSS configuration file is parsed externally.

This method is deprecated and must not be used when the object is constructed using the default constructor. In the past, it pulled configuration information out of the XML doms constructed into the object and into configuration variables for both the module level and channel level configuration parameters.

refsect1.para: See DATATYPES and PUBLIC ATTRIBUTES for more information about the data we store in this object. Note that this object now does not actually execute code but servers as a data storage object whose data are used at start up time to configure a digitizer.

refsect1.title: DATATYPES
refsect1.para: The data types exported are needed to express the values of various, more complex, configuration parameters.

listitem.para: This enumerated type provides the sorts of coincidence modes that are allowed at the second level board trigger. Allowed values are Or for a trigger from either channel of the couple, And for a trigger requirement of both channels of each couple and Majority to use the majority level trigger.

This enumerated type provides for an expression of the trigger source. Valid values are internal; in which case only channel based triggers will trigger readout, external; in which case only external triggers will trigger readout or both in which case either an external or internal trigger will trigger acquisition.
Provides channel trigger information. This consists of the following fields:

The channel number this struct describes. Descriptions are sparse in the sense that disabled channels are not described. Thus each per channel data struct inidicats the channel it describes and all channels not described are just disabled.
This is trueif the channel participates in coincidence/majority level triggering or false if not.
Describes the type of coincidence trigger the channel participates in. This is used to set bits 8-9 of register 0x8180+4n
The majority level for majority triggering. Sets bits 10-12 of register 0x8180+4n
The coincidence window for coincidence/majority triggering. Used toset bits 20-23 of register 0x810c

refsect1.title: PUBLIC ATTRIBUTES
refsect1.para: The public methods of instances of this class are filled in by the compass configuration file processor. Note that several configuration parameters are defined but don't appear to actually have meaning with respect to the current board firmware. Explanation of those attributes are omitted for brevity.
These have the following meanings:

listitem.para: Flag that specifies the acquisition mode. Specifically, a 1 here specifies that only processed DPP data will be transferred to the data buffer. A value of zero means that in addition to processed DPP data, selected trace data will be inluded in the data buffer. See dualTrace and analogTrace1 as well as analogTrace2 below.

This is used as the delay parameter when constructing the CAENPha object that will control the board associated with this configuration. This value is in nanoseconds and will be converted to an appropriate register value to program the board start delay (register 08170).
Trace length acquired.
Per channel coincidence/majority trigger configuration.
Acquire waveforms. This must be used with the acquisition mode set to mixed to include the acquired waveform data in the data buffer.
If true, two waveforms, selected by analogTrace1 and analogTrace2 are included in the databuffer for each channel hit. If false, only the trace selected by analogTrace1 is included.
Note, this requires that the acquisition mode be mixed and that waveforms be true.
Selects analog probe 1. In single trace mode, this is the only trace included, in dual trace mode, this is the first of the two traces. This value is an integer in the range [0..3].

0 means the trace is the input waveform. 1 means this trace is first derivative of the input. 2 mean this trace is the second derivative of the input. 3 means this trace is the output of the trapezoid filter.
If dual trace mode is enabled with the inclusion of waveforms in the data buffer, this is a value in the range [0..3] that selects the second trace included in the waveform data.

0 means this trace is the input 1 means this trace is the threshold referred to the waveform second derivative. 2 means this trace is the current Trapezoid baseline. 3 means that this trace is the computed baseline.
Describes what triggers the board responds to. See the TriggerControl data type for information about the meanings of this value.
provides the start mode parameter to the CAENPha constructor.

In spite of the best efforts to synchronize digitizer boards, there may be a constant offset between timestamps between different boards. This value is subtracted from the raw time tag values from the board after any rollover has been accounted for to widen the timetag to 64 bits and before the timstamp is calibrated to nanoseconds.
Per channel parameters for enabled channels. The first element of each pair is the channel number. The second element the per channel parameters.

refsect1.title: DESCRIPTION
refsect1.para: This class is an event segment that encapsulates a CAENPha object. The object is configured using a matching module in an XML configuration file produced by the COMPASS data acquisition program from CAEN.

Before diving into the methods, a word about COMPASS and COMPASS configuration files. COMPASS is a CAEN data acquisition program that can be used to optimize the configuration of DPP-PHA and DPP-PSD digitizers. COMPASS can run a group of synchronized digitizers simultaneously and includes a wizard for synchronizing the digitizers. It writes XML files that capture the configuration of the digitizers it is running.

COMPASS XML files describe a group of digitizers. CompassEventSegment only operates a single digitizer. The digitizer in the XML files that matches the connection paramters passed to the constructor of CompassEventSegment is used to supply configuration data for the module run by this event segment.

refsect1.title: METHODS
refsect1.para: Note that the virtual methods in CompassEventSegment provide and implement the interface to CEventSegment. These will not be descdribed here as they are adequately described in the NSCL documentation set.

listitem.para: The linkType, linkNum, node and baseAddress parameters provice the connection information that allows the CAEN digitizer library to talk with the digitizer. These are also compared with the connection parameters in the configuration file to determine which digitizer described in filename provides the configuration for this module.
Finally, the pCheatFile, if not null provides a cheat file for the CAENPHa object enclosed by this class. See the doucmentation for CAEENPHa for a description of cheat files.
Interfaces to the multi module CAEN trigger class. This method returns true if there is either un-submitted internally buffered data or the module has data in its buffers that can be read now.
Part of the multi-module synchronization support. If the module is configured as the synchronization/clock master, returns true.

If the board is a master, it must be the last board started andyou must use startMaster to start it. Normally, if you are using a CompassMultiModuleEventSegment, that class takes care of getting everything started in the right order,
If the board is a slave on the clock and synchroniziation daisy chain, this this method should be called after configurtion to prime the board to respond to the hardware start signal.

refsect1.title: PUBLIC Attributes
refsect1.para: The module has a set of counters, two per channel. These are 16 bit counters that describe the number of triggers and number of missed triggers. It's possible to arrange for these to be included in the event data.

If this feature is enabled, m_countersActive will be true. In that case, m_lastTriggerCounts is an array of the 16 bit trigger counts for each channel and m_lastMissedTriggerCount, the count of missed triggers.

Because they can roll over relatively rapidly on a macroscopic time-scale, the 16 bit counters are relatively useless. The m_triggerCount and m_missedTirgges arrays account for rollovers and maintain 32 bit counters
One use of this feature is to create a scaler bank from CAENPHAScalers to turn these values in to scalers that can be displayed on the NSCLDAQ scaler display program.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Create scaler readouts from DPP-PHA trigger counters.

refsect1.title: DESCRIPTION
refsect1.para: This class associates itslf with the trigger counters of a CAEN DPP-PHA digitizer. The constructor is given the event segment as a pointer and, whenever a scaler readout is triggered, makes two scalers from the trigger count and missed trigger counts for each channel in that order.
srcid in the constructor provides the source id to be associatd with the scaler readouts.

refsect1.title: DESCRIPTION
refsect1.para: This class is a container for CompassEventSegment objects. It supports managing several DPP-PHA modules as a single event segment. There are some tricks that need to be played in order to get a synchronized start and fair readout. This class plays those tricks.
Once constructed, clients can add modules to the event segment by calling addModule.
The remainder of the methods implement the CEventSegment interface.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Parse Compass XML file module definitions.

refsect1.title: DESCRIPTION
refsect1.para: This class implements the parser for the COMPASS XML Configuration files. It accepts the path to the configuration file as the constructor parameter file. operator() then processes the file building public data from which the configuration can be pulled.

refsect1.title: PUBLIC Types and Attributes
refsect1.para: The opertor() processes the enteri configuration file. This results in a set of connection parameters and configurations of the board at each connection.

The client software matches up connection parameters with actual board connection parametes and uses the corresponding configuration to configure the board. For the client software to do its job, data are exported.
The class defines one public data type of use; the ConnectionParameters. The fields of this structure contain the connection parameters that describe how a digitizer is connected to a host system:

listitem.para: The type of link to the digitizer. See CAENDigitizerType.h in the CAEN digitizer library installation include file directory for legal values.
The link number. This is mainly used for optical links where there may be more than one optical interface per system and selects the specific optical interface daisy chain the board is on.
Indicates the node of the interface system (position on optical daisy chain or USB system), at which the board lives.
For modules controlled via a VME controller, this is the base address configured into the module's rotary switches.

refsect1.para: Two attributes are also exposed to clients:

listitem.para: This vector are the decoded parameters (board and per channel) for each board described in the configuration file.
For each element of the m_boards configuration array, this array will have a corresonding entry that describes the connection to that board.

refsect1.title: DESCRIPTION
refsect1.para: CompassTrigger provides an event trigger which will be satisfied when any member board has data that can be submitted to Readout's ring buffer. Note that it's not necessary for these data to be held in hardware fifos. Each module contributes several hits per read, but only one hit can be emitted per trigger. Therefore the event segments hold the remaining hits in internal buffers.

A trigger could be responded to by providing a hit from an internal hit buffer that has not yet been emitted or by reading a module, buffering its data and then emitting the first hit from that buffer.
The addModule allows the client to add a module that will be polled during the call to operator().

section.title: DPP-PSD support classes.
section.para: DPP-PSD support is provided by classes that are described in this section.

refsect1.title: DESCRIPTION
refsect1.para: The CCompoundTrigger class aggregates triggers from a variety of sources and performs the logical OR on them when checked. Thus if any component trigger is set, CCompoundTrigger is set.

After construction, addTrigger can be used to add component triggers to the class. Once a trigger is raised, it is still the responsibility of the event segment(s) to perform a fair readout so that no single event source can starve any other event source.

refsect1.title: DESCRIPTION
refsect1.para: Manages a single DPP-PSD module. Module configuration comes from the module configuration stanza in a COMPASS configuration file that has connection parameters that match those passed to the constructor of this object.
Note that the configuration file is processed every time a run starts so changes to the configuration file made after a run starts will be reflected in the next run.

refsect1.title: METHODS
refsect1.para: In this section we're only going to document the methods that are not part of the CEventSegment interface. The CEventSegment interface methods are documented sufficiently in the NSCLDAQ documentation.

listitem.para: This constructor establishes the connection parameters for a board and the COMPASS configuration file that will be processed to determine how to configure the board and its channels.
linkType, linkNum, node and base are the link parameters that must exactly match the connection parameters of one of the boads described in the COMPASS configuration file indicated by configFile

This method returns true if this board is configured to be the timing master. The timing master board must be started last as it will emit hardware signals to start the slave boards in a synchronized manner.
If this board is configured as a timing master, it is started. If the board is configured as a timing slave, it is primed to start on receipt of the start signals emitted by the master.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Only alow one contribution into an event segment

refsect1.title: DESCRIPTION
refsect1.para: For CAEN Digitizer readouts, each trigger should only produce one hit in a ring item. If you are mixing together several CAEN-DPP event segments, you need to put them together using this compound event segment class. A typical use case is combining DPP-PHA and DPP-PSD readouts.

After constructing the object, use addModule to add the event segments you need. The read method responds to the trigger by asking its event segments in a round robin way to contribute data. Once data are contributed, read stops and remembers where it left off. Fair readout is done by responding to the next trigger by first asking the next module after the one most recently producing data to contribute. For this purpose, the modules are treated as if they form a circular list in the order in which they were added to the segment.
This round robin scheme should prevent low rate modules from being starved of the opportunity to contribute data to the output ring by higher rate modules.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Manage a chain of DPP-PSD modules

refsect1.title: DESCRIPTION
refsect1.para: This class allows you to build an event segment out of a set of DPP-PSD Modules. THe segment is presumed to be a time-synchronized daisy chain with a timing master and several slaves.
Build the list by constructing the individual module objects, constructing this class and then invoking addModule to add each module object to the CPsdCompoundEventSegment.
When initialize is called, each contained module is asked to initialize. The code then primes all the slave modules to start and finally, starts the timing master module.

There is nothing to stop you from building an object consisting entirely of slaves. This will most likely be done when using COneOnlyEventSegment to mix both DPP-PSD and DPP-PHA modules. In that case, all slave modules will be synchronized and when the timing master in another segment is started, all will start in a synchronized manner.
In a singles experiment, where timing synchonization isn't important, you can just as easily program all modules as masters and all will start up but unsynchronized.

When the object's read method is invokded a fair, round robin scheme is used to request data from modules so that low rate modules will not be starved by high rate modules. This is done by treating the modules as a cirular list and, after a module hit is received, responding to the next read call by starting to look for data beginning with the next module in the object.

refsect1.title: DESCRIPTION
refsect1.para: CPsdTrigger is CEventTrigger that polls a set of CDPpPsdEventSegment> objects to determine if any of them have data ready to send to the output ring buffer. Note that these objects may have internally buffere data or data buffered in the digitizer module they manage.
addModule is used to incrementally build up the set of objects that will be polled by this trigger object.

refsect1.title: DESCRIPTION
refsect1.para: This data only struct contains the configuration data that can be applied to a single channel of a DPP-PSD digitizer. See also PSDBoardParameters and PSDParameters, which hold the the entire parameters for one board (including a vector of PSdChannelParmeters), and parse an entire compass file for DPP-PSD modules.

listitem.para: In a syncrhonized system, the start pulse travels down the module daisy chain. Because of propagation delays, cable lengths and the time it takes each module to output the start after seeing it on the input, each module will get the start pulse a little later than the previous module on the daisy chain.

s_channelTimeOffset allows you to compensate for this timing skew by programming a delay into each module between receiving the start pulse and actually starting (it's the start that zeroes a module's timestamp counter). By programming successively longer delays as you go towards the master module, you can get a much better synchronization of the timestamp clear in all modules. Naturally, an external start with a star cabling configuration and measured cables, makes this unecessary at the cost of external hardware.
This value is expressed in nanoseconds and converted by the module initialization code to register values.

This enumerated field is used to inform the channel of the signal input polarity to expect. Legal values are either positive or negative. It is necessary to program tis properly (as well as setting the DC offset for the channel to keep the signal inside the dynamic range of the digitizer), because the DPP algorithms all operate on a positive going pulse. If a channel has been programmed as negative, the signal will be digitally inverted prior to the DPP-PSD algorithm.

The leading edge discriminator trigger threshold value. When the (possibly inverted) digitizer value is above this value, the channel declares a trigger. Note that better timing on the trigger time can be gotten by enabling the CFD.

Contains an enumerated type that selects the number of samples to average when computing he signal baseline value. Note that after a trigger, baseline computation is, of course disabled and the baseline frozen for a settable period of time.
Valid values are:
The baseline is not computed from input signal but, instead is a programmable fixed value.
A running average of 16 consecutive samples is used to compue the baseline value.
The baseline is computed from a running average of 64 consecutive samples.
A running average of 256 consecutive samples is used to compute the baseline.
A running average of 1K samples is used to compute the baseline
A running average of 4K samples is used to compute the baseline.
A running average of 16K samples is used to compute the baseline.
This parameter is only meaningful if the CFD is enabled. It is the CFD delay parameter in nanoseconds. Initialization code converts it to register values appropriate to the actual digitizer.
If true this channel is enabled. If false, the channel is disabled. Disabled channels will not buffer data nor participate in module trigger decisions.
This value is an integer between 0 and 4 inclusive and selects the input smoothing value. Note that the smoothed input can be used by both the CFD and LED.
0 means input smoothing is disabled. 1 means two samples are averaged to smoothy the input 2 means 4 sample 3 means 8 samples and 4 means 16 samples.

Sets the pile up rejection gap. See register 0x1n7c. The pi8le up rejection gap determines the threshold at which a pile up is detected when the signal rises again after falling off. This value is set in digitizer conversion units.

The XX725 and XX750 digitizers have dual dynamic ranges. This parameter selects the channel's dynamic range. Legal values are vpp2V which sets a 2V peak to peak range and vpphalfV which sets a 0.5V peak to peak range (half).

To provide pulse shape discrimination information, the digitizer integrates the value of the signal over a short gate and a long gate. s_shortGate determines the length of the short gate in nanoseconds. This value is converted to register units by the initialization code.
This parameter is only used if the CFD is enabled. It determines the CFD fraction value. Legal values are:
25% scaling factor (1/4).
50% scaling factor.
75% scaling factor
No scaling done (100% scaling factor).
Selects the type of discriminator that will be used. led uses a leading edge discriminator while cfd employs a constant fraction discriminator.
If a fixed baseline is used, this is the value of that baseline. The integerized version of this value will be programmed into the fixed baseline register (0x1n64).
The trigger hold off in nanoseconds.
Long integration gate length in nanoseconds.
Channel DC offset value in percentage of full scale (that is 0-100).
The coarse gain selector expressed as femto Coulombs per least significant bit of the integration returned. This is one of:
Least significant bit is 2.5 fC
Least significant bit is 10 fC
Least significant bit is 40fC
Least significant bit is 160fC
Least significant bit is 640fC
Least significant bit is 2650fC.
Nuber of nanoseconds of integration prior to the gate.
Nanoseconds of waveform capture prior to the trigger.

refsect1.title: DESCRIPTION
refsect1.para: This data member only struct contains the data required to configura a single DPP-PSD digitizer module (board). It includes the per channel configuration data in the s_channelConfig array.

listitem.para: Contains a textual version of the model of the digitzer, e.g. V1725. This is gotten via a call to CAEN_DGTZ_GetInfo once the digitizer has been opened.
Contains the module serial number. This is gotten from the module via a call to CAEN_DGTZ_GetInfo once the digitizer has been opened.

Contains the type of connection used to access the digitizer. LinkType can be either usb or conet Note that these two encapsulate both direct connection to the digitizer or connection via a USB/conet VME bus bridge.

The number of the link used to connect the host to the digitizer. This is most often non-zero for conet when it selects the specific optical link that connects the host to the digitizer, or the CONET/VME bus bridge controlling the digitizer.

The node number of the digitizer on the interface (link) it's attached to. For CONET daisychains, his is clear and easy to figure out. For destktop digitizers connected to USB, you'll probably have to probe...and then be sure not to move cables around so that renumertions hold the node numbers constant.
For digitizers that are interfaced to the host over VME interfaces, this is the digitizer's base address. For all other digitizers, this should be zero.
Speed of the digitizer ins picoseconds/sample.

If true the digitizer will be enabled to accept an external clock. In general internal clock should only be used for stand-alone digitizers and for master digitizers in a synchronized daisy chain (though even then an external clock could be used).
If true then the list mode, DPP parameters extracted from the waveform will be included in the digitizer output. If false, only waveforms will have valid values.
Selects the module trigger coincidence mode. This can be one of:
No coincidence requirement. THis is the same as triggering on the or of a couple trigger.
Both channels in a couple must fire (couple AND requirement).
Channel pairs require a motherboard trigger as well.
A single channel can veto the trigger.
Selects the condition required for the digitizer to start accepting triggers. This can be one of
A software start will zero the timestamp counter and begin acquisition. This is suitable for stand-alone modules and masters on a synchronized daisy chain of modules.

The module will start taking data when it senses a true going edge on the SIN front panel input. Prior to this, a software start must have been issued to arm the module. This is suitable for slaves in a synchronized daisy chain or all modules if an external start is used to start data taking, rather than a master module.

Data takings starts on the first external trigger. The module must first have been armed to accept this start via a software start. This is suitable for slave modules on a synchronized daisy chain and for all modules in a synchronized set if an externally generated start pulse is used
If true, the detection of a valid coincidence trigger will output a pulse on the TRGOUT output.
Currently this field is not used. Digitizers are always programmed to produce a time tag.
The digitizers have a calibrtaion function. If this field is true the calibration will be performed prior to loading the digitizer configuration.
Currently unused. I believe the intent is that if true, the module will be software triggerred when it is started. We use software start and daisy chain hardware starts instead of this.
Currently unused. The intent is that if true, the so-called extra1 and extra2 data will be included in the data bufferded for each event in the digitizer.
Length of waveform captured in nanoseconds.
Nanoseconds after start pulse or software start the module actually zeroes its timestamps and is able to take data. This is used to get
If true, enables waveforms to be recorded in the data buffer along with the results of the DPP computations.
An enumerated type that selects the signalling level on the front panel. Legal values are nim and ttl
Selects which signal will be presented to the TRG OUT lemo. Legal values are:
Continuously de-assserted.
Continuously asserted.
Pulses when a software trigger has been requested of the module.
Pulses when an external trigger has been input to e.g. the TRG IN Lemo connector.
Pulses when the motherboard generates a global OR trigger.
Logical true when the board is running.
True when the board is running after a start delay.
Echoes the clock sent to the ADCs to accept samples.
Echoes the clock input to the PLL clock.
Asserted when the digitizer is busy.
Asserted when the PLL has lost lock.
Presents the selected virtual probe.
Reflects the S-IN input.
Contains the 16 per channel parameter structs. Note that not all of them may be actually used, for example, in desktop digitizers.

refsect1.title: DESCRIPTION
refsect1.para: This class is responsible for processing a COMPASS configuration file and producing, as a result a vector of PSDBoardParameter objects. The method parseConfigurationFile simple takes pFilename which is a pointer to the character string path to the file to process.
